Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Learned how to evaluate arguments and critically analyze them
I learned how to write a philosophy paper.
Reasoning.
That philosophical issues around death, at least the way that they are covered in this class, are not of particular interest to me.
How to think about death and my emotional response to it from a logical perspective
This is an interesting course, which provides one with considerable food for thought about death from many different angles.
Great intro to philosophy with an incredibly interesting topic
I learned how to structure philosophy essays and think logically.

I learned how to philosophically approach the question of death, looking at questions such as: Do we have souls, or are we simply bodies? Is immortality desirable? What makes death bad? Is suicide morally permissible?
How to think about death in a different way
How to write a philosophy paper
Thinking about topics that are difficult to grapple with.
I learned how to think and respond philosophically

I learned a great deal about the mind-body dualism, souls, personal identity, rationality, and death. Beyond the course material, the structure of the class (sections, grading, etc.) taught me a lot about developing succinct, clear, and robust arguments which I'm sure will prove helpful in all of my courses at Yale.
I got my first taste of philosophical thinking and writing at the college level.
I learned about how to process, discuss, and write about philosophy.

It was great to have a clearer and more structured conception of the arguments on either side of the issues around death, including helpful titles for them such as The Deprivation Account. I have thought a decent amount about the content of this course before taking it, but it was always in fairly nebulous terms and in a confusing, unstructured way, so that structure is one of the most valuable things I took from this course.
How to think deeply about a subject and then discuss it
Thinking philosophically
I learned about a variety of basic philosophical arguments regarding death (and also life).

Coming into the course, I had no knowledge of how to write a philosophy paper and didn't love that style of writing. However, coming out of the course, I grew to really enjoy philosophy papers and looked forward to my weekly discussion section. I learned to think critically about what it means to die, understand the reasons for which death is considered bad, and the rationality and ethics of suicide. I believe this class made me a better critical thinker, writer, and listener.
I gained critical thinking skills and began to think of death in a more complex way than before taking this class.
I had great opportunities to contemplate about what is death and life. The name of the class is Death, but it is at the same time, about life.
My critical and logical reasoning skills definitely improved, along with my essay writing skills.
Considerations about life, death, and philosophy about these topics.

This course challenged me to confront many of my own preconceived beliefs about faith and death. It was truly a journey, and I am very grateful to have had the opportunity to take a step outside of my comfort zone and approach my faith from an objective and philosophical standpoint. It also taught me to be accepting of new ideas, as well as the importance of understanding why it is believe what we do.

This is a wonderful introductory philosophy course! I learned how to think critically about beliefs that I have never questioned previously. I also learned how to write a philosophy paper and participate in discussion.

This course provides a crash course in several fascinating subtopics within analytic philosophy: Questions about the existence of the soul; about the possibility and (un)desirability of immortality; personal identity theory; the goodness and badness of death; and the rationality and morality of suicide. In addition, it does something that not all philosophy can claim to do: it raises some questions that, in attempting to answer them, you may find that your behavior and thoughts about life outside of class will change. As someone who lost two close family members early in the semester, it was very valuable to obtain a structured approached to thinking about the almost unfathomable questions about life and death.

The course covered a number of philosophical debates about various aspects of death- from whether a soul exists, to whether immortality would be desirable, to whether suicide can be permissible. The course helped me understand the various viewpoints within these debates and introduced me to the skills required to think about, plan and write philosophy papers.
I developed philosophical and argumentative thinking, discussion and writing skills. I also gained a lot of insight into thinking about death.
Good intro philosophy course. Improved skill in writing philosophy papers and thinking about the issues of death that seem counter-intuitive at first.
This was a life changing course for me!
A general understanding of death, souls, and mortality, and increased philosophical vocabulary.
A introductory philosophy course meant to introduce students to techniques of philosophical thinking and writing with an extremely interesting subject matter: death.

A gentle walk-through of philosophical ideas around death. By taking this course, I developed my logical thinking, communication skills via discussion and obtained a more calmed attitude towards life and death.

This was my first philosophy class, so I learned a lot about the basics of how to ask questions like a philosopher. I also had never thought too deeply about death in an academic way, so I learned so much about how to think about death and ask questions about the topic.

This course gave me a space to grapple with the topic of death, as well as many other related beliefs: the existence of souls, personal identity and change over time, is death really "bad," and more. At the end of the day, rather than shoving information down our throats, Shelly offered us perspectives on these issues and challenged us to formulate our own beliefs and arguments. I also feel like I am much better at writing a "philosophy paper" and with lucid argumentation in general.
I really enjoyed learning about the Philosophy of Death and the many arguments behind it.
Basic philosophical analysis of metaphysical and ontological issues. Writing and analysis skills in philosophy.
Better understanding of how to approach philosophical questions. Insight into how to think about death, which kind of scares me.
philosophy skills of writing a paper
Learnt to think critically and philosophically, and got a lot of new perspectives on life and death
Sections are very different and grades seem to heavily depend on the TA and how well that TA is able to objectively and accurately judge discussion participation and papers

Shelly is pretty clear about what he expects, which is great. He is also really helpful when it comes to providing feedback. However, I wish he wouldn't end his arguments with statements like "Well maybe I'm just delusional." In a class so focused on constructing good arguments, this seems like a terrible last step.

I really like the unconventional format of Shelly spending the course trying to convince you of his beliefs (and doing a damn good job of it). It forces you to challenge your own thoughts and come up with more coherent arguments to defend your own views, especially if they are at odds with his. There is no wishy-washy "both sides are equally truthful" sort of stuff.
The lectures are often repetitive, and unfortunately not in a way that reinforces learning, but rather one that engenders boredom.
I really like the lecture-section structure and readings designed to give us adequate background information
Get rid of the ridiculous curve! You can also literally not go to class and watch every lecture online, which I was a bit disappointed in.

Shelly is an interesting lecturer, though sometimes the course feels like it is meandering a bit, which can cause one to lose a bit of interest. Overall, though, the content is very thought-provoking.
Professor Kagan is great. I enjoyed the dynamic lectures and thought the topics were interesting and enlightening.

Strengths 
The Professor is a good lecture and the material is interesting
Weaknesses
I just think that the class was so one sided because we were only learning about the professors beliefs on death. The biggest one being the non exsistance of souls. Our entire course was shaped around that and though I found it interesting to look at it from this perspective. Something was lost in not putting multiple views about souls in conversation with each other throughout the course.

Professor Kagan's lectures were great and always engaging. He is truly one of the best lecturers at Yale. The course material was very interesting and was an interesting way to think about such weighty questions.
Too reppetitive at times
There needs to be consistency with regards to TAs and fairness in grading
The sections are extremely beneficial, especially not having computers. The lectures were not that engaging though.

The positive parts of the course are also the negative partsit's not a class for everyone, but for the people that take the class very seriously, it's undoubtedly a valuable experience. In section, you receive three participation grades (the semester is broken down into 3 parts). The participation grades force students to engage with the section discussions, and the nature of the grades being divided into three parts means that students receive pretty constant, clear, and fairly-objective feedback while maintaining room for improvement throughout the semester. I found that the level of engagement/contribution in my section was way higher than other courses. The class is pretty self-selecting because of its difficulty, so you'll be surrounded by incredibly smart and engaged students. The TA's are also very willing to discuss the topics outside of class / meet to work on papers, which is really helpful. These aspects of the course are really only bad insofar as you want a class that won't significantly challenge you. Aside from those, the only real weakness I saw was that the class was highly abstract (in my opinion), and it was hard to stay motivated sometimes when the topics felt so impersonal/distant.

Shelly is an incredible lectures and lectures are always engaging and worth going to. 

Readings are manageable, interesting, and well tied to the material presented in class.

Papers topics are fun to engage with  I would recommend discussing your ideas with your TA before sitting down to write so you get them clear in your head and so that you can talk it through.

I think the topic and discussion section were strengths. I thought the class could be improved if it focused more on important philosophers' views on death. We read Plato, but few other well known philosophers. Topics like nihilism, existentialism, absurdism might have been interesting to cover.

Shelley was a very compelling lecturer who never failed to engage us in his material. The subject of "Death" is complicated, but Shelley made it digestible by walking us through every topic and especially putting a lot of attention into the basic philosophical concepts we covered at the beginning of the course.

A strength of the course was definitely the discussions we had in section. The people in section were really interested by the material, and we had some great (albeit sometimes heated!) discussions. Another strength was Shelly himself, who is a pretty engaging lecturer (most of the time; see below). The course was also structured in a good way, going from a discussion of souls, to whether death is bad, immortality, suicide etc. I also really enjoyed how open Shelly was to taking questions and comments from the class, and then debating them. It was interesting and impressive!

I also liked how my TA was open to me exploring my own ideas in the papers which diverted a bit from the exact arguments we discussed in class. This was also (in a way) actively encouraged in the final paper.

A weakness was that Shelly often repeated content, and also spent quite a bit of time on hypotheticals to explain fairly intuitive concepts or dilemmas. This meant sometimes lectures could be a bit slow or boring, despite Shelly's high-energy speaking/lecturing style.

The classs lectures were interesting and Shelly is a good lecturer. I would say the improvements would be to nix the readings entirely or include the readings more in lecture/section. I was doing readings that were never discussed for the whole semester.

I think the course was very strong, as Shelly Kagan is probably the most engaging professor I've had thus far at Yale. The course examines death from many different perspectives and gives you the opportunity to discuss those perspectives and think critically about what your own perspective is. My only complaint is that suicide could have been talked about a little more sensitively.
Everything was great except sometimes I felt like it was a tad bit unorganized in lecture but Shelly always made it back on track.

The strengths are definitely Shelly's lectures. They were incredibly interesting and intellectually challenging. I also liked the essay prompts. One improvement may be to have smaller discussion sections.
This is a fantastic course. Only strengths. Lecture was fantastic, and section was captivating.
This was an excellent course. Shelly and the team of teaching fellows were exceptionally transparent, accessible, and engaging. Very well-organized.

Shelly Kagan is an incredible lecturer, best I've listened to at Yale so far. Very engaging, entertaining and funny. Weaknesses: toward the end it gets slightly repetitive and less interesting because he completely avoids the ultimate question of the class: after learning what we have about death, what is even the meaning of life?

Shelly is a great lecturer- fun, enthusiastic and compelling. My TA was also excellent at moderating discussions and ensuring we all got our say in section.

Some improvements could be made with the syllabus- somewhere in the middle, the topics seem to be a repetition of the same metaphysical questions that seem a bit too detached from reality, and interest tends to a drop a little.
I really enjoyed the discussion sections component in addition to the lectures. The lectures were especially engaging when Professor Kagan gave ample examples, which he did.
The course covers interesting material, but often moves very slowly. Shelly is an engaging lecturer and does a good job explaining the material.
It was very well organized. Shelly was one of the best professors I've ever had.

A tried-and-true course that has been taught every year with little changes, it runs smoothly with the number of students who want to take a class with Professor Kagan. The grading scale is notoriously difficult, assigning an arbitrary curve that depends totally on the quality of the individual sections led by different TA's that can make it very variant.
Very difficult course, hard to understand how to succeed. Abstract grading system.

Strength: the combination of lectures and sections provides a great opportunity for students to share their ideas and thinking, either in a mass of people or in a small group. The course content and structure are also well-designed and very illustrative. Sections are well-moderated well.

Potential improvement: in lectures and sections, it could be better if we could refer to, relate to, or reflect on those reading materials. Some of them have been covered and discussed, explicitly, in class already; others are not, yet reflecting on them more frequently, either in lectures or sections, might help us better understand and appreciate those materials, as well as incentivize us to allocate more time reading them.
Sometimes I felt like Shelly took longer than was necessary to make his point or could be redundant. But a major strength was how interesting and new (to me at least) the questions we went over were.

Strengths: Professor grades based on improvement
Weaknesses: Professor grades very strictly
topics tend to go surface level, without significant depth. Paper prompts are sometimes narrow or restrictive.
Really great lectures, no real weaknesses. It's clean and well-structured.
It's very good.
Yes, an interesting course with no work besides the papers
Yes! Take it!

Near-death experience. The course is not easy and the essays are harshly graded. The course material, however, is very interesting and intellectually stimulating. Chapeau to Shelly - he is the reason why I took the course, an amazing Professor.
Not unless the student wanted a professor who will grade her writing honestly. That's the only perk of this class.
Yes.
Be very cautious in taking this course as a letter grade. Shelly is notorious for his tough grading, and it applies here.

Only is you are not already familiar with philosophy or really have an interest in the specific aspects of death and philosophical issues surrounding death that are covered in this course. Alternatively, it is also a good option if you are quite good at philosophy and need a gut.

I would recommend this course, especially Credit/D. Shelly is a great, engaging, and thoughtful lecturer, sections are really just a matter of showing up and talking, the readings are interesting but short and non-essential, and the three 5-page papers are very easy to manage. The papers themselves can be graded harshly but if you are a good writing and know how to give the TA what he/she wants, you can get an A or A- relatively easily.
No, you can take the class online for free basically. Use your credit elsewhere
Difficult to overstate how light of a workload this class is. A 5th crafted by the Gods old and new.

Death is a fantastic class, just like everything else Shelly teaches. I also took intro ethics, which I think was slightly more interesting. Hearing Shelly lecture is an experience everyone should have. Talking to him after class is also amazing.

The grading is fair in that if you write well and make good points, then you will get a good grade. It is harsher then most classes at Yale, but it is definitely not arbitrary.

I would recommend this course to another student who is interested in the concept of death or simply wants to engage with some philosophical thought. That said, the grading is remarkably unforgiving, so I'd very strongly recommend taking it Credit/D/Fail, especially if the student is new to philosophy and philosophical writing.
Incredible dive into philosophy of death
Yes, I would. I looked forward to waking up for this class. The lectures were entertaining and interesting.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student, whether it is their first philosophy course or they have a strong philosophy background. Professor Kagan is a great lecturer and the material was really interesting.
Yes its a great intro class
Yes, very interesting and engaging lectures! Course was challenging on a personal and intellectual level. Improved my writing tremendously (if you put in the effort). Not easy.
Yes. I took this course at a time I was going through an existential crisis; and this course helped show me a different side to the crisis.
Yes!
Yes, it was very eye opening and interesting, but take it credit D.

If you have a very strong interest in philosophy and want to take a class that will challenge you, then I would certainly recommend this class. It's probably smartest to start out with Credit/D/Fail and then maybe switch if the first paper turns out well. If you're not sure about how strong your interest is in philosophy, then I would only take this class Credit/D/Fail. Even if you love it, it's easy to slip up and do poorly on a paper even when you work hard on it.
Take this!!! I would start it credit d but you may be able to change it  you just need to put the effort and work into the papers.
Yes. I thought it was interesting during both lecture and section.
Yes, both for the intellectual challenge and to say you took a lecture with Shelley Kagan. His complicated material and tough grading style make the class a very worthwhile challenge.
I would, especially if they are interested in the material but haven't yet read or thought much about it.
This class is great for a credit/D- Shelly is a fantastic lecturer and I found the material to be fascinating. If you take it for a grade, know that grading is a bit difficult.
Yes
Yes. The topics were really stimulating and fun to think about.

This class low key sucked. One of the biggest problems I had with the course was that section participation (which made up 25% of the grade for the class) was graded on a curve centered around a mid B. This turned section essentially into a competition, which was not conducive to productive conversation. Instead of being a time to have interesting conversations about the lectures and readings, sections were stressful and unpleasant. Rather than being rewarded for listening to other students and responding to their points in a thoughtful way, students were rewarded for speaking up the most frequently. In addition to the unproductive sections, I also found class lectures to be disappointing. I found many of Shelly's arguments to be hastily-made and unconvincing. Shelly has much better classes than this. I would recommend taking one of those.

This class is good, but doesnt really live up to the hype. The lectures are interesting and Shelly is a good professor, but the topics are kinda shallow. To be fair, I am a STEM major who has never taken a philosophy class who took it Credit/D/Fail, but it wasnt quite my cup of tea. In addition, the complaints about Shellys grading are unfoundedthe class is straightforward, and with some assistance from the TAs, you can definitely pull off a B at least without overexerting yourself.

I would recommend this course to any student interested in philosophy, as I think the topic matter is applicable and interesting to anyone. The material is made very graspable and accessible and I believe it was a great introduction to philosophy.
Yes, absolutely. Death is one of the best classes that I have taken at Yale.
Yes! This class is a classic for a reason and you won't be disappointed.
Absolutely. Regardless of academic interest it is a fantastic class.
Super interesting class! Shelly is an engaging and compelling lecturer! Definitely would recommend.

Please-- for the sake of yourself, Yale, and the true value of a liberal arts education--take this course. Without a doubt, Shelly is one of the most engaging lecturers I have encountered here and the material is powerful, insightful, thought-provoking. As a person of faith, I was slightly afraid that I was wandering into the snake-pit, but this course challenged me to confront many of my own preconceived beliefs about religion and death. It was truly a journey, and I am very grateful to have had the opportunity to take a step outside of my comfort zone and approach my faith from an objective and philosophical standpoint. It also taught me to be accepting of new ideas, as well as the importance of understanding why it is believe what we do. My faith was only strengthened by the challenges of this course (sorry, Shelly), and, for once, discussion sections were actually enjoyable. TAKE IT--by studying death, you may even learn more than you think about life. It may be wise to begin this class C/D/F, just don't let yourself graduate without taking a class with Shelly. That would be a shame.

Yes! Highly recommend this class (take it credit D though)! It is a good introduction to a college philosophy class- with an incredible professor! Very though-provoking and unique. Seems like an experience you will never get again outside of college/Yale, so I recommend taking it if you have any interest in philosophy!
Don't do it. Not even Credit/D.

Highly recommended to majors and non-majors alike. As a class that contains elements of analytical philosophy, while still being an intro course, majors should be aware that section isn't always *that* analytically rigorous, while non-majors should be aware that this is very far from a literary or psychological approach to questions of death, and lectures will sometimes be rather abstract and esoteric. All that said, a fantastic class.
If you plan to take a course with Shelly, I would recommend Intro to Ethics over this class.

Yes, definitely! It's a very enjoyable class which you can get a lot out from. Shelly is great fun to listen to and the questions he raises will get you discussing the topics with everyone around you.

This is a interesting course and serves as a great introduction to philosophical and  argumentative thinking and writing. Shelly Kagan is an incredible scholar and a great lecturer, so the lectures are an experience. The discussion sections are also quite fun. The class focus on death does not necessarily make it morbid, but rather gives a lot of perspective in thinking about our mortality. If youre interested in becoming exposed to philosophical thinking while not having too much extra work, take this course Credit/D.
Shelly is a great lecturer and this is a course that forces you to confront difficult uncomfortable questions. Take it C/D/F.
Yes, absolutely.
Yes

Yes definitely, as a non-humanities major, it was very interesting to take a pure humanities course and was on my bucket list before graduating. The course is fascinating since discussing death means you must also discuss life. I had many conversations with friends outside the class about what we talked about in lecture and it was always very interesting.
No. It was an interesting course but the actual material had to take a backseat to understanding the grading structure, which was unnecessarily difficult.
It's very doable, and a good introduction to Philosophy.

I watched some clips of this course online years before I came to Yale. It is absolutely a great opportunity to sit in the classroom and enjoy the introduction, analysis and discussion of different ideas about death. The class is very energetic and vibrant. More importantly, the sections provide a venue where twelve or so students could gather and discuss life and death every week, with moderation of a thoughtful TA. This is actually the greatest in-curricular experience I have ever had at Yale. Overtime, I can sense my improvement in logical thinking, group discussion, elucidating abstract and complex ideas, as well as a more thorough and thoughtful attitude towards life and death. Highly recommended for those who love thinking and care about the meanings of life and death.

I absolutely loved this class. The material is relevant and engaging. It was very well taught, from both professor and TF. I found the workload to be practical and even enjoyable, and I feel I got something out of every single lecture, section, and assignment. I would highly recommend this course.
no

This course is a good way to begin studying philosophy, as Shelly is a very clear and engaging lecturer. In my opinion however, just beware that this course will present to you a detailed view of one side of an argument. Three weeks or so are spent considering whether or not the soul exists, at the end of which it is decided that there is apparently no soul (personally, I did not find the presented arguments convincing enough to lead to this conclusion). Afterwards, the remainder of the course focuses on the other aspects of death with this underlying assumption. It is an intriguing class and you will learn much about the physicalist perception of the value of life and death. However, I had hoped to learn more of the other positions held regarding the soul, life, and death which I felt were scarcely conveyed through this class.
Yes! Really animated professor and fascinating topic. After almost every section or lecture, I found myself continuing the conversation with friends.

Yes, I would definitely recommend this course to another student. Although you can get deep into the philosophy and complicated arguments, all of the actual material is very accessible and relevant to any person. I think just about anyone can take away a number of lifelong insights from this course.

Would recommend to a student interested in gaining an introduction to philosophy. Would not recommend for students with background in topics on metaphysics. Also would nto recommend to students who have already viewed/participated in the free class/lectures online.
It's super philosophical, thought-provoking, the essays are super fun.
Absolutely. Gives you new perspectives on life and I found the essays really fun to write and Shelly is a great lecturer
